articles.headline: Regulators Vow to Find Way to Stop Rapid Dives
articles.snippet: The agreement comes as investigators looking into last week’s market plunge have focused on how a controlled slowdown on the N.Y.S.E. set off uncontrolled selling on electronic exchanges.
articles.abstract: The agreement comes as investigators looking into last week’s market plunge have focused on how a controlled slowdown on the N.Y.S.E. set off uncontrolled selling on electronic exchanges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal financial regulators forged ahead on Monday to try to prevent a repeat of last week’s roller-coaster stock ride, though they had not determined the cause of the sudden, steep decline in prices on Thursday.

articles.headline: After S.E.C. Suit Warning, Traders Flee Moody’s Shares
articles.snippet: The company said it had received a notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission on March 18, warning of possible legal action.
articles.abstract: The company said it had received a notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission on March 18, warning of possible legal action.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of Moody’s fell sharply on Monday after it disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had warned that it might sue the firm for making “false and misleading” statements as part of its application as a ratings organization.

articles.headline: Discount Store Is New York Beachhead for Nordstrom
articles.snippet: While retailers of Nordstrom’s caliber typically come to New York to erect sumptuous flagships, Nordstrom is introducing itself with a low-cost sister store in Union Square.
articles.abstract: While retailers of Nordstrom’s caliber typically come to New York to erect sumptuous flagships, Nordstrom is introducing itself with a low-cost sister store in Union Square.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than a century, Nordstrom, the upscale department store chain from Seattle, will make its Manhattan debut on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Debt Aid Package for Europe Took Nudge From Washington
articles.snippet: President Obama advised German Chancellor Angela Merkel that Europe needed to try something big.
articles.abstract: President Obama advised German Chancellor Angela Merkel that Europe needed to try something big.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Obama had just flown into Hampton, Va., Sunday morning to deliver a commencement address. But before he donned his silky academic robes, he was on the phone with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, offering urgent advice — and some not so subtle prodding — that Europe needed to try something big.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger, Katrin Bennhold and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Kagan Nomination Leaves Longing on the Left
articles.snippet: Like other Democratic nominees since the 1960s, Elena Kagan does not fit the profile sought by the left, which hungers for a liberal counterweight to Antonin Scalia.
articles.abstract: Like other Democratic nominees since the 1960s, Elena Kagan does not fit the profile sought by the left, which hungers for a liberal counterweight to Antonin Scalia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The selection of Solicitor General Elena Kagan to be the nation’s 112th justice extends a quarter-century pattern in which Republican presidents generally install strong conservatives on the Supreme Court while Democratic presidents pick candidates who often disappoint their liberal base.

articles.headline: A Pragmatic New Yorker on a Careful Path to Washington
articles.snippet: Elena Kagan charted a deliberate path — never revealing too much of herself — that led her to the spot she occupies today.
articles.abstract: Elena Kagan charted a deliberate path — never revealing too much of herself — that led her to the spot she occupies today.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON —  She was a product of Manhattan’s liberal, intellectual Upper West Side — a smart, witty girl who was bold enough at 13 to challenge her family’s rabbi over her bat mitzvah, cocky (or perhaps prescient) enough at 17 to pose for her high school yearbook in a judge’s robe with a gavel and a quotation from Felix Frankfurter, the Supreme Court justice.
articles.byline: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG, KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and LISA W. FODERARO

articles.headline: Karzai’s Warm Reception Reflects New U.S. Approach
articles.snippet: Abandoning its tough approach to Afghanistan’s president, the White House is welcoming Hamid Karzai to Washington with a new charm offensive.
articles.abstract: Abandoning its tough approach to Afghanistan’s president, the White House is welcoming Hamid Karzai to Washington with a new charm offensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time Afghanistan’s president, Hamid Karzai, was in Washington — a year ago — he had to share the spotlight with his Pakistani counterpart, Asif Ali Zardari, who got the bulk of the attention from the White House, the Pentagon and the State Department. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton even made a personal, unscheduled visit to huddle with Mr. Zardari at his hotel.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: A Trillion for Europe, With Doubts Attached
articles.snippet: The wisdom of the rescue package’s main component, a promise of new loans to bail out European economies, was challenged by some analysts.
articles.abstract: The wisdom of the rescue package’s main component, a promise of new loans to bail out European economies, was challenged by some analysts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like the giant financial bailout announced by the United States in 2008, the sweeping rescue package announced by Europe eased fears of a market collapse but left a big question: will it work long term?
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Money Managers Remain Hesitant on Euro Bailout
articles.snippet: Analysts said the huge budget deficits most European governments were facing would not be fixed by a bailout package.
articles.abstract: Analysts said the huge budget deficits most European governments were facing would not be fixed by a bailout package.
articles.lead_paragraph: Markus Krygier is betting against the euro — still. Not even $1 trillion was enough to change his mind.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: A Trillion for Europe, With Doubts Attached
articles.snippet: Some analysts challenged the wisdom of the rescue package’s main component, a promise of new loans to bail out European economies.
articles.abstract: Some analysts challenged the wisdom of the rescue package’s main component, a promise of new loans to bail out European economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like the giant financial bailout announced by the United States in 2008, the sweeping rescue package announced by Europe eased fears of a market collapse but left a big question: will it work long term?
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Cameron Takes Over as British Premier After Brown Resigns
articles.snippet: David Cameron, the Conservative leader, became prime minister. Nick Clegg will become his deputy as the Liberal Democrats approved a coalition deal.
articles.abstract: David Cameron, the Conservative leader, became prime minister. Nick Clegg will become his deputy as the Liberal Democrats approved a coalition deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s Conservatives returned to power on Tuesday after 13 years in opposition when David Cameron, who has built his future on a claim to have recast the party of Margaret Thatcher for a new century as more compassionate and less class-bound, took over as prime minister from Labour’s Gordon Brown.

articles.headline: U.S. to Split Up Agency Policing the Oil Industry
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is proposing splitting the agency that oversees offshore drilling in response to the Gulf Coast oil spill.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is proposing splitting the agency that oversees offshore drilling in response to the Gulf Coast oil spill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday proposed breaking up the agency responsible for both policing the oil industry and acting as its partner in drilling activities, seeking to end a decades-old relationship between industry and government that has proved highly profitable — and some say too cozy — for both.
